column13: Fix ls bug
column20:
Steps to reproduce bug:

Turn on monpolycontrol
^G a chameleon into yellow light form
let it die

On death, the chameleon's data is set to &mons[PM_CHAMELEON].
m_detach() was checking mon->data "should this monster emit light".
It was not considering mptr, which would have said "this monster used to emit light".
TODO:
Actually store ls pointers (and timers?) on monsters and objects instead of in the processing chain, so that we can more easily check "does X have an attached lightsource"
column21:
Steps to reproduce bug:

Turn on monpolycontrol
^G a chameleon into yellow light form
let it die

On death, the chameleon's data is set to &mons[PM_CHAMELEON].
m_detach() was checking mon->data "should this monster emit light".
It was not considering mptr, which would have said "this monster used to emit light".
TODO:
Actually store ls pointers (and timers?) on monsters and objects instead of in the processing chain, so that we can more easily check "does X have an attached lightsource"

column13: Add new artifact: Bloodletter
column20:
unaligned (iron) morning star
+1d8 to hit and +1d12 blood damage

Deals extra bonus blood damage at lower health. At under 50% of maximum health, deals an additional +1d12 for a total of +2d12. At under 25% of maximum health, deals an additional +1d12 for a total of +3d12.


When invoked, self-impales (dealing damage equal to 20% of your max hp, can be lethal) to coat in blood. This lasts for 20 + 2z9 turns. While coated in blood:

Appears as "sanguine" in your inventory.
Damage dealt is also treated as energy damage, in addition to being blunt and piercing.
Deals an extra flat +defender level damage to monsters with blood.
Hitting high level monsters during this time can decrease the amount of time remaining on the blood coating. It subtracts defender_level/10 - rn2(5) (rounded down) from the time remaining, and never adds more time.
Can be applied to slam down, releasing the tainted blood. This ends the active effect but causes a 6d6 rotten blood explosion. The explosion only hurts creatures with blood, and also deals a flat +defender level damage to affected creatures.

unaligned (iron) morning star

Damage dealt is also treated as energy damage, in addition to being blunt and piercing.

column21:
Corrections:

When under 50% hp, deals an additional 1d12 damage to creatures with blood (stacking with previous 1d12)
When under 25% hp, deals an additional 1d12 damage to creatures with blood (stacking with previous 2d12)


Bloodletter does not multiply its base damage or enchantment.


Invoke duration is 20 + [0-9] + [0-9] turns; not 20+2d10.

Edit: main description has been updated with these corrections.

column13: Newsym pets to give them the correct highlight immediately
Tweak wishing for rematerialed objects
column20:
If your wish couldn't get you the material you want, give a random material, not last-on-the-list.
I'm also considering disallowing wishing for rematerialed objects. Most variants with obj materials do that.
Grunthack doesn't, but in Grunthack the player needs every edge they can get over the evils of the dungeon. dNethack characters tend to be strong enough without also having dragonhide speed boots and cloaks of protection.

Grunthack doesn't, but in Grunthack the player needs every edge they can get over the evils of the dungeon. dNethack characters tend to be strong enough without also having dragonhide speed boots and cloaks of protection.

column13: Fix drowning issues
column20:
Before instant death, drowning first uses up your breath meter. This puts you underwater as though you were amphibious. Moving next to a crawl-able escape instantly and immediately brings you to shore (as before). This may need to be adjusted in the future for balance / verisimilatude.
Teleports do not consider 3D-water to be safe if you can only survive in it by holding your breath.
Fixes infinite drowning-loop on the plane of water.

Buff crystal plate mail to be the premier AC/DR option.

Separate light/medium/heavy from size again

column13: Check that rectangle corners are in-bounds
Fix xpathto's memory allocation
column20:
It allocated an Cx(R+2) length block of memory:
Ex: C=8, R=2. This is one continuous block; the end of one line goes to the start of the next
000000000
000000000
000000000
000000000

Then would loop over an inner portion to mirror the game map, of size (C-1)xR:
Ex: "l" is where is being looped over
000000000
0llllllll
0llllllll
000000000

And would check if one square is "adjacent" by adding/subtracting the right amount (+1, -1, +C, -C, +C+1, +C-1, -C+1, -C-1).
In most places, this would cause it to correctly access one of the designated non-looped portions (marked by a 0 in the examples).
In one place, this would cause it to access unallocated memory:
Ex: X is the looped-over spot, and Z is the unallocated memory being accessed
000000000
0llllllll
0lllllllX
000000000Z

Easiest fix: allocate that one more byte of memory.
Also, improve the commenting of that function.

column13: Revert changes made to remove_rooms(); use different Spire-Dispensary…
column20:
… fix
Turns out I made a big mistake changing remove_rooms().
The roomno of parts of levl[][] wasn't being cleared when rooms were.
This rolls back remove_rooms() to prior to that change, which reintroduces the issue of the dispensary stairs appearing behind the Spire.
Fixes that issue by forcing the dispensary stairs to appear in one of the prior levels (it can never appear on the spire level now).

column13: Change ranged weapon balance
column20:
Why:
Bows suck too much for casual use. Unenchanted ammo with a non-artifact bow is just horribly low damage, even at Expert skill. Throwing daggers or darts is much better than using a bow. No more!
What:
All ammo fired from a launcher now gets +Skill damage, except for guns. This buffs bows and slings; crossbows already got skill damage from their precision.
To compensate, several bow artifacts were nerfed:
Ranger quest artifacts changed from 2x damage to +1d6. For +7 arrows, that's a net change of -2 per arrow.
Epoch's Curve bonus damage reduced from +1d6 to +1. It now returns artifact arrows fired, though they are slower to return.
Plague's invoke changed to not increase the critical filth rate.
Sunbeam and Moonbeam received changes to how quickly they return after being fired, particularly in conjunction with Epoch's Curve.
The following bow artifacts were not changed:
Yoichi no Yumi, the Lawful Samurai crowning gift. It still has less DPR than an Elven Ranger wielding Belthronding.
The Bow of Skadi, the Neutral Valkyrie crowning gift.

column13: Add more artifact encyc entries
Make boulders scary
column20:
Like for rolling boulder traps, thrown boulders follow through on-hit, although their range halves every time they hit.
Boulders knock back creatures hit 1 tile. This happens before the boulder moves.
Buff the accuracy and damage of rolling boulder traps.
Bugfix to make monsters actually throw boulders.

1+2 together makes for much deadlier thrown boulders. Thankfully, there's a 1/3 chance that you'll be thrown slightly to the side when hit by a boulder, interrupting the ouch-train.
Worst-case, you'll be hit ~5 times before a boulder reaches its resting point.
Yes, these can knock you back into traps or water or lava.
Yes, this may need to be toned down. In the meantime, good luck and have fun!

column13: Fix gigantic holes in untame() bugfix
ID and mitigate potential corruptions of monster movement loop
column20:
If a monster's actions cause the next monster in the fmon chain to be moved to the migrating_mons chain, the nmtmp pointer will cause the loop to go through the migrating_mons chain -- this is BAD.
Check that each new mtmp in the loop is on the level (by checking mx and my).
If the monster is migrating, we cannot use its ->nmon. We also cannot trust the previous mtmp to still be on the level, even if we had a pointer back to it. For a perfect solution, we would need a list of every monster handled by the loop so far.
Instead, we will restart the loop at fmon again.
This will double-process any monsters that were already handled AND have >=12 movepoints remaining, letting them get their second move earlier than expected (in relation to other creatures' movements) this global turn. I think that this is minor enough to be unnoticable, especially with how rare the trigger event is in the first place.
I have tested this and it appears to work. (ie, I can reproduce the weeping-angel levelports monster causing panic without patch, and then attempting to reproduce it with the patch fails)
column21:
If a monster's actions cause the next monster in the fmon chain to be moved to the migrating_mons chain, the nmtmp pointer will cause the loop to go through the migrating_mons chain -- this is BAD.
Check that each new mtmp in the loop is on the level (by checking mx and my).
If the monster is migrating, we cannot use its ->nmon. We also cannot trust the previous mtmp to still be on the level, even if we had a pointer back to it. For a perfect solution, we would need a list of every monster handled by the loop so far.
Instead, we will restart the loop at fmon again.
This will double-process any monsters that were already handled AND have >=12 movepoints remaining, letting them get their second move earlier than expected (in relation to other creatures' movements) this global turn. I think that this is minor enough to be unnoticable, especially with how rare the trigger event is in the first place.
I have tested this and it appears to work. (ie, I can reproduce the weeping-angel levelports monster causing panic without patch, and then attempting to reproduce it with the patch fails)

column13: Check mtyp is valid
Massively nerf flaying weapons
column20:
Armor destruction:

"lesser" flaying weapons only apply at all 1/3rd of the time
"greater" flaying weapons disenchant by 1, not 2-4.
"Thorns" disenchants by 1-3, not 2-7.
also check visibility of messages.

Movepoint loss:

"lesser" amount doubled for effectively 2/3rds as much when combined with above
"greater" amount reduced to 2/3rds as much
"Thorns" amount doubled to be equal to "greater".

Hopefully these changes will make being in melee with an enemy with a flaying weapon less terrible for your gear.
This comes after seeing Malcanthet destroy a fully-enchanted piece of endgame gear with each swing.

column13: Fix "foo's helmet blocks your attack to their head" msg
Adjust Mitre/EotOW to be appropriately sized
column20:
As-is, the EotOW are completely unwearable on a chiropteran monk - since you can't resize lenses/sunglasses, and yet they only fit appropriately sized characters. The Mitre is better, but it still needs a resizing & a body plan (longhead & animaloid) adjustment.  The Noble crowning helms should probably be appropriately sized, even if they would fit anyway, with the body plan adjusted as well.
I only adjusted those since they are unusable in their current state (EotOW) without adjustments (Mitre, crowning helms). Other potential artifacts would be Itlachiayaque, the Veil of Latona, Hermes' Sandals or the noble quest artifacts. I don't really think they need to be poked - no clue about Latona but I think Hermes' Sandals would be sized for Hermes' (who apparently has a medium humanoid avatar), and Itlachiayaque is an ancient artifact and usable as-is anyway. Lastly, the noble cloaks aren't even obtainable as a funkily sized race right now - chiro/gnomes can't be nobles. Though I think chiro rangers, gnomish arcs, and gnomish healers might have poorly fitting artifacts right now.
Note that you can still get crowned with the noble pantheon as a Chiropteran to receive the helms, so they're added in here as well despite not being normally obtainable. Obviously this doesn't fly for the cloaks. Amusingly enough, before this, a Chiropteran priest crowned as a noble could have the helm put on directly, bypassing the standard body plan checks, but would be unable to put it back on without adjustment if doffed.
Also added lenses/sunglasses to the "sized equipment" bit of the mkobj.c code. That doesn't include artifacts, so it's mostly irrelevant, but could definitely be noticed.

column13: Close lockfile properly
column20:

column13: Nerf knockback artifacts
column20:
The following changes only apply to knockback inducing artifacts -- not jousting, boulders, staggering strikes, or other methods of causing mhurtle(),
Full knockback is now a chance, based on the strength of the blow and the defender's remaining hp. Uses dieroll instead of rn2() for crit-like behaviour -- your better and best blows cause knockbacks.
Full knockback will not happen to creatures too large to be thrown.
If the chance fails, drain a small amount of movement and stun.
Buff ideas for affected artifacts are welcome:

Rod of the Ram (!)
Hammerfeet (!)
Scepter of Might
Rod of Dis
Staff of Wild Magic

Buff ideas for affected artifacts are welcome:

Rod of Dis
Staff of Wild Magic

column13: Nerf Argentum golems' ranged damage
column20:
They fire 1d4 -> 1d3 silver arrows.
When monster ranged was generally buffed, it affected these guys heavily, with +4d8 damage per arrow.
Seeing as people haven't found the buffed golems impossibly nasty (and they certainly feel mini-boss-like now), I'm keeping the nerf minor to hopefully avoid a player being one-shot.

column13: Rework Oracle, adding enlightenment and dungeon inclusion hints
column20:
Also migrates the dialogue to a menu, instead of the series of y/n/q it was before.
Enlightenment retails for 200 + 20 * level, and works identically to a standard wand zap.
Glimpses of the future gives a random hint about the various set-on-game-start inclusions - Gae vs. Tulani spawns, Dracae vs. Polypoid vs. Tulani spawns, the Platinum Dragon's airship, your
chaos variant, and Oona's elemental affinity. Did my best for vaguely flavorful messages for each option, trying to have fun with it, but I'm not super set on any of the messages.
Also lowers the xp gains from the oracle a tad, mostly for simplicity & consistency between them. Maximum xp for the curious would be a minor consultation followed by a glimpse of the future for levels 0-10, and minor followed by major for 10+, assuming you haven't checked in with her before.

column13: Nerf Octetsabers
column20:
Consider the other lightsaber artifacts: they don't really make the lightsaber much stronger, even the Annulus.
An octetsaber, at max luck, was over 2x damage compared to an unsocketed lightsaber (at max enchantment. more like 4x damage when comparing at +0).
Post-nerf, an octetsaber at max luck will be a bit more damage than an unsocketed lightsaber (average of +5 flat per hit; doubled for doublesabers).
Removes unlit octetsabers entirely. An Octahedron shouldn't boost damage if it isn't actually being used as the weapon -- putting an Octahedron into a sack won't make you deal 1d8 expl-lucky when swinging the sack around, so it shouldn't affect a lightsaber that isn't actively using its focusing gem!

column13: Use anonymous unions where appropriate instead of #define
column20:
Absolutely better than using the union v_whatever {} in object.h and trap.h, possibly preferable to using #define elsewhere too.
Makes coding easier because the IDE knows that the alternatives are subvariables of the main struct. With the #define hack, the IDE doesn't realize it until you're finished typing.
Note: does not work identically when in conjunction with bitfields; only using #define is able to stuff multiple names into the same 2 bits.
Probably doesn't break saves and could be merged into compat as well, but I don't wanna risk it.

Note: does not work identically when in conjunction with bitfields; only using #define is able to stuff multiple names into the same 2 bits.
Probably doesn't break saves and could be merged into compat as well, but I don't wanna risk it.

column13: Change timer backend
column20:
Now saves with each object, instead of as the global loop. Greatly reduces tomfoolery when attaching/detaching pointers.
Handling is done for objects and monsters, though there are no monster-timers yet.
Handling for levels/global is possible, if we ever want to do so.

column13: Summons!
column20:
Apologies for the commit history; I had to merge in compat-3.20.0, and this is also based on the timer rework.
Important commits are at the bottom.
Summoned creatures disappear when their summoner dies or leaves the level.
Summoned creatures' items disappear when the creature dies or leaves the level.
Many forms of monsters summoning other monsters use this, with notable exceptions:

minion gating (melee gating and monster spell)
raising the dead (monster spell)
wizard duplication

Summoners are prevented from doing more summons once they have their HD-worth of summons active on the field.
Demon-gating is back in, but following summoning rules. Kill the original, and they all go poof; and each one has a limit (of its HD) on how many (and strength of) enemies it can bring out.

column13: Recalculate vision on setworn()

column13: Prevent cursed offhands slipping when weldproof
column20:
When starting twoweaponing with the offhand cursed, or when the
offhand weapon becomes cursed whilst already twoweaponing, it no
longer drops to the ground.
The only case not considered here is losing the weldproof effect whilst
already twoweaponing, by e.g. curing lycanthropy
One can imagine that you already have a really tight grip on the weapon
knowing that you'd otherwise lose it - this is the little-known strategy
'using your imagination to avoid fixing edge cases'
Removes an unused variable and reduces scope for another one
Closes #1453

already twoweaponing, by e.g. curing lycanthropy
One can imagine that you already have a really tight grip on the weapon
knowing that you'd otherwise lose it - this is the little-known strategy
'using your imagination to avoid fixing edge cases'
Removes an unused variable and reduces scope for another one

column13: Special case the artifact iron ball at pickup
column20:
The artifact iron ball of levitation actually improves your carrycap by
its weight whilst carried.
If you have limited carry capacity for any reason, say you're a gnome
or you've read scrolls of punishment, you may not be able to pick it up
to benefit from that effect.
This special cases the check in the number of objects you can pick up,
as well as the guard for warning about encumberance
Closes #1412
column21:

column13: Fix impossibles from wishing for partly eaten/drained foodstuffs
column20:
The code to set nutrition of partly eaten/drained items was improperly setting the nutrition to 1 at times when it it shouldn't be - like for tins and wraith corpses, which both have base nutritions of 0.
This would give an impossible, which is now fixed.
Also includes a minor refactoring, adding the vanilla obj_nutrition function to replace most ocurrences of objects[otmp->otyp].oc_nutrition / mons[otmp->corpsenm].c_nutrit or whatever. Since I copy-pasted it with modifactions, there's now some minor nutrition related changes (elves get +25% nutrition from lembas, orcs get -25%, and dwarves get +15% from cram).
Also fixes the long-standing bug where drained corpse wishes always ended up with 1 nutrition "over-drained" corpses (oeaten wasn't being set, leading to trying to reduce from 0 rather than the base nutrition, hitting the minimum nutrition of 1).
Note that now, a partly eaten wraith corpse wish will just fail to make it partly eaten - since there's no real way to denote a partly eaten 0 nutrition corpse in the current code. A partially drained one will just give you a 'drained' corpse that can't be drained again, but is the same nutrition, due to the isdrained field.
I would not be opposed to somebody testing the hell out of this - I spent 5 minutes or so wishing for random things and consuming them, but I'm not sure it's bug free at all. Hopefully.
column21:
The code to set nutrition of partly eaten/drained items was improperly setting the nutrition to 1 at times when it it shouldn't be - like for tins and wraith corpses, which both have base nutritions of 0.
This would give an impossible, which is now fixed.
Also includes a minor refactoring, adding the vanilla obj_nutrition function to replace most ocurrences of objects[otmp->otyp].oc_nutrition / mons[otmp->corpsenm].c_nutrit or whatever. Since I copy-pasted it with modifactions, there's now some minor nutrition related changes (elves get +25% nutrition from lembas, orcs get -25%, and dwarves get +15% from cram).
Also fixes the long-standing bug where drained corpse wishes always ended up with 1 nutrition "over-drained" corpses (oeaten wasn't being set, leading to trying to reduce from 0 rather than the base nutrition, hitting the minimum nutrition of 1).
Note that now, a partly eaten wraith corpse wish will just fail to make it partly eaten - since there's no real way to denote a partly eaten 0 nutrition corpse in the current code. A partially drained one will just give you a 'drained' corpse that can't be drained again, but is the same nutrition, due to the isdrained field.
I would not be opposed to somebody testing the hell out of this - I spent 5 minutes or so wishing for random things and consuming them, but I'm not sure it's bug free at all. Hopefully.

column13: Tobiume now tases enemies
column20:
Tobiume still deals +1 fire damage, but the on-death explosions and invoke now deal a combination of fire and shock explosions. It also gives both fire and shock resistance when wielded, up from just fire.
If the unskilled invoke is used (single beam), the damage type is chosen randomly. If the skilled invoke is used (cluster of explosions), the damage type is chosen randomly and independently for each explosion.
For the on-death explosions:

If the monster resists fire but not shock, it will use a shocking explosion
If the monster resists shock but not fire, it will use a fiery explosion
If the monster resists neither fire nor shock, it will use either one with a 50% chance each
If the monster resists both, it will use a fiery explosion

Also fixes a minor missing period if the player does not have enough energy to use the shikai.

column13: Fix x/y asymmetry in small-radius darksources
column20:
A radius-0 circle uses the same circledata as a radius-1 circle, so when calculating the y-boundaries, also use a minimum-1 radius.
Otherwise, y will calculate to +-0, while x (taken from circledata) will be +-1.
column21:

column13: Monster Blindfold Patch
column20:
Implement monsters wearing and picking up blindfold class items. Monsters will favor living masks, then sunglasses, then android visors.  I'm not sure any of these do anything for monsters yet other than living masks, and potentially sunglasses.
Androids will prefer to wear android visors. Monsters will not put on blindfolds, towels, or ebon panes by default but they can be put onto them manually. Mind flayers will put on ebon panes.
This implementation does not actually make worn opaque facial wear blind monsters. See "Monster Blindfold Patch With Blindness".
column21:
Implement monsters wearing and picking up blindfold class items. Monsters will favor living masks, then sunglasses, then android visors.  I'm not sure any of these do anything for monsters yet other than living masks, and potentially sunglasses.
Androids will prefer to wear android visors. Monsters will not put on blindfolds, towels, or ebon panes by default but they can be put onto them manually. Mind flayers will put on ebon panes.
This implementation does not actually make worn opaque facial wear blind monsters. See "Monster Blindfold Patch With Blindness".

column13: Monster Blindfold Patch With Blindness
column20:
This is a potential addition to the Monster Blindfold Patch that comes at an unknown tradeoff. This implements opaque blindfold items actually blinding monsters. This is problematic currently because we do not have mon->blindf or any other non weapon worn object pointers for monsters yet.
This means every single Is_blind check done has to do an O(n) traversal of the monster's inventory. This sounds very unideal and I have no idea how this affects performance. Playtesting seems fine but this may be a good time for someone to profile with and without the change.
This doesn't check things like opaque crystal helmets but it easily could be modified to in the future.
column21:
This is a potential addition to the Monster Blindfold Patch that comes at an unknown tradeoff. This implements opaque blindfold items actually blinding monsters. This is problematic currently because we do not have mon->blindf or any other non weapon worn object pointers for monsters yet.
This means every single Is_blind check done has to do an O(n) traversal of the monster's inventory. This sounds very unideal and I have no idea how this affects performance. Playtesting seems fine but this may be a good time for someone to profile with and without the change.
This doesn't check things like opaque crystal helmets but it easily could be modified to in the future.

Monsters now are seen via warning as their apparent form ("warned of elvenkings" etc). For example, a goblin appearing as an elvenking will still be detected by Sting, but the farlook message doesn't give away that it isn't actually an elvenking you for some reason have warning of.

column13: Fix buffer overflow in tty menus
Patch a couple clang warnings
`makemon()` can now directly specify template and faction to apply
column20:
Actually, makemon() behaves exactly as it did before, but I've added another version, makemon_full(), where those things are specifiable.
Things that affect monsters being of a template (other than directly being specified as such by makemon_full()) belong in makemon_set_template().
Things that... ...faction... ...belong in makemon_get_faction().
This was as much of a kerfuffle as it was because monster placement will take templates into consideration. If we were to add an "atlantean" template that gives monsters waterbreathing, and called makemon_full() with it (or the level defaulted to putting that template on monsters), the monster will accept being spawned in water. This was not possible (as cleanly) before.
I was able to kill mkmon_template, but curhouse is needed for peaceminded(), and I didn't want to try to dig into mkzombie() for zombiepm and skeletpm.
column21:
Actually, makemon() behaves exactly as it did before, but I've added another version, makemon_full(), where those things are specifiable.
Things that affect monsters being of a template (other than directly being specified as such by makemon_full()) belong in makemon_set_template().
Things that... ...faction... ...belong in makemon_get_faction().
This was as much of a kerfuffle as it was because monster placement will take templates into consideration. If we were to add an "atlantean" template that gives monsters waterbreathing, and called makemon_full() with it (or the level defaulted to putting that template on monsters), the monster will accept being spawned in water. This was not possible (as cleanly) before.
I was able to kill mkmon_template, but curhouse is needed for peaceminded(), and I didn't want to try to dig into mkzombie() for zombiepm and skeletpm.

column13: New artifact: "Mask of Many Faces"
column20:
Neutral mask
Invoke while wielded or worn against a target adjacent creature.
If the creature is below 1/3rd hp (1/6th for uniques), kills them leaving no corpse. The Mask then assumes the shape of the slain monster.
When worn (or immediately, if it was invoked while worn), the player is polymorphed into the form of the Mask, including for no-poly monsters.
The duration of the polymorph is dependent on the relative level of the player to the monster, reduced significantly for no-poly monsters. Unchanging cannot be used to make the effect permanent.
While poly'd, the mask can be re-invoked to end the effect early.
column21:
Neutral mask
Invoke while wielded or worn against a target adjacent creature.
If the creature is below 1/3rd hp (1/6th for uniques), kills them leaving no corpse. The Mask then assumes the shape of the slain monster.
When worn (or immediately, if it was invoked while worn), the player is polymorphed into the form of the Mask, including for no-poly monsters.
The duration of the polymorph is dependent on the relative level of the player to the monster, reduced significantly for no-poly monsters. Unchanging cannot be used to make the effect permanent.
While poly'd, the mask can be re-invoked to end the effect early.

column13: Dynamic artifacts, randarts!
column20:
Dynamically resizes the artifact arrays as needed to add new artifacts at will during a game!
Randarts can have names up to 63 characters long (PL_PSIZ).
Randarts are de-artifact-ed when making bones.
The randart-generating function is a work-in-progress, is not called anywhere, and is just as much there to stress-test the functionality of the dynamic-artifact code than it is expected to generate real artifacts in a real game. I expect that the function will see significant changes and improvements before the code is accessible in a normal game.
column21:
Dynamically resizes the artifact arrays as needed to add new artifacts at will during a game!
Randarts can have names up to 63 characters long (PL_PSIZ).
Randarts are de-artifact-ed when making bones.
The randart-generating function is a work-in-progress, is not called anywhere, and is just as much there to stress-test the functionality of the dynamic-artifact code than it is expected to generate real artifacts in a real game. I expect that the function will see significant changes and improvements before the code is accessible in a normal game.

column13: Fix some missing `isok()` checks
Replace "Antimagic Shield" with "Abjuration"
column20:
No one used antimagic shield and the spell was kinda boring. Kick it to the curb and say hello to Abjuration!
It attempts to dispel all adjacent summoned monsters. If they fail their resist(), they vanish. If they succeed their resist(), if they were a temporary summon to begin with, their duration is reduced (permanent summons are fully immune when they resist).
I gave it a quick test, and was it ever effective against the nastiest spellcasters, so I bumped it up to being a level 7 spell.
column21:
No one used antimagic shield and the spell was kinda boring. Kick it to the curb and say hello to Abjuration!
It attempts to dispel all adjacent summoned monsters. If they fail their resist(), they vanish. If they succeed their resist(), if they were a temporary summon to begin with, their duration is reduced (permanent summons are fully immune when they resist).
I gave it a quick test, and was it ever effective against the nastiest spellcasters, so I bumped it up to being a level 7 spell.

column13: Oops
Suppress `rloc()`'s impossible in a safe circumstance
column20:
A teleporting monster that already has a place on the map should not cause an impossible() when rloc() fails to find a new place for it. This can happen when the level is full, and the monster's current place is no longer acceptable (eg a boulder has been added to it). However, this is fine, since the monster remains in place.
Adjust behaviour appropriately: the monster that failed to teleport is still able to take other actions.
column21:
A teleporting monster that already has a place on the map should not cause an impossible() when rloc() fails to find a new place for it. This can happen when the level is full, and the monster's current place is no longer acceptable (eg a boulder has been added to it). However, this is fine, since the monster remains in place.
Adjust behaviour appropriately: the monster that failed to teleport is still able to take other actions.

column13: Check that mplayers have names before reading them.
Numina doesn't grant Omnisense
column20:
Numina already grants DETECT_MONSTERS, which is level-wide monster detection. This is what it should be.
What OMNISENSE does is make infrared/blood/life/earth/all 'sense' cover the whole level, but these visiontypes are treated as 'sight' and not 'sense', which makes for awkward "I can see the foo, interrupt current action".
column21:
Numina already grants DETECT_MONSTERS, which is level-wide monster detection. This is what it should be.
What OMNISENSE does is make infrared/blood/life/earth/all 'sense' cover the whole level, but these visiontypes are treated as 'sight' and not 'sense', which makes for awkward "I can see the foo, interrupt current action".

column13: Skip des coordinate sanity checks
column20:
This allows an optional flag, [skipcheck] or [noskipcheck]
to prevent / force the coordinate check routine.
Presently it's only implemented for objects, monsters, and engravings.
If this ever needs extending with more categories, it would be worthwhile
to instead extend the coord data type and track a skip flag there,
but I wanted to keep it pretty simple here

column13: Rehack circlet desc on restore
Fix projectile reflection possible infinite loops
column20:
I must have originally written all projectiles to pass through on MM_MISS, then changed it later (thus causing the issue of "hey Sansara doesn't work anymore"
Putting in a continue to skip to next projectile movement worked, but only if a reflected projectile had range == initrange, which is a problem with potential infinite loops.
The continue did NOT skip to next projectile movement. It skipped to "start the projectile loop again", which would avoid re-hitting because of another idiosyncracy where a projectile with range == initrange wouldn't try to hit the creature currently on the square (assumed to be the originator of the projectile), and only then get to the next "move the projectile by dx/dy".

The MM_REFLECT feels a little overkill (I don't like muddling up that particular set of #defines) but I dunno how better to return the info of "projectile was reflected", since checking range==initrange is it's own badness.
column21:
I must have originally written all projectiles to pass through on MM_MISS, then changed it later (thus causing the issue of "hey Sansara doesn't work anymore"
Putting in a continue to skip to next projectile movement worked, but only if a reflected projectile had range == initrange, which is a problem with potential infinite loops.
The continue did NOT skip to next projectile movement. It skipped to "start the projectile loop again", which would avoid re-hitting because of another idiosyncracy where a projectile with range == initrange wouldn't try to hit the creature currently on the square (assumed to be the originator of the projectile), and only then get to the next "move the projectile by dx/dy".

The MM_REFLECT feels a little overkill (I don't like muddling up that particular set of #defines) but I dunno how better to return the info of "projectile was reflected", since checking range==initrange is it's own badness.

column13: Expand `deadmonster` to 2 bits to mark 'dead' as well as 'purge'.
column20:
DEADMONSTER() generally just needs the 1st bit, but we want the 2nd bit to be sure that we're only purging monsters once.
Set the 1st bit when we would previously be setting (or confirming) that monster hp <1 and isn't recovering.
Set the 2nd bit after unlinking.
Fixes issues of monsters dying because of mongone()/mondead()/etc before they reach m_detach().
column21:
DEADMONSTER() generally just needs the 1st bit, but we want the 2nd bit to be sure that we're only purging monsters once.
Set the 1st bit when we would previously be setting (or confirming) that monster hp <1 and isn't recovering.
Set the 2nd bit after unlinking.
Fixes issues of monsters dying because of mongone()/mondead()/etc before they reach m_detach().

column13: Force split worm parts to be level 3 or higher

level 0 worm parts or 0 hp worms with d0 rolls

so I only took the change to the minimum level
Fixes #1911

column13: Variable-speed single actions
column20:
This takes what was previously being done with moving (reduced movement point cost under certain conditions) and generalizes it for attacking and future expansion into other action types.
Attack actions now cost less (or more) movement points at the place where movement points are deducted, instead of giving/costing movement points in attack2() (note: that function can be renamed back to attack() now).
Shows action type and time taken in status bar, for wizardmode in curses only, for my debugging.
TODO: create more MOVE_xyz flags and work my way through the various functions that currently return 1 for time taken and 0 for instant, to be able to do things like "this artifact makes drinking potions take less time" etc.

column13: Remove special case double-counting Ana Drow binder spirit
Remove special case double-counting Ana Drow binder spirit
Allow spiritual rapier attacks to (conditionally) hit insubstantial targets
column20:
Since by default all varieties of spiritual rapier are shining, which allows them to phase armor, it makes sense that they should count as shining for hitting insubstantial targets (shade, hudor kamerel, etc.) as well.
There are currently message handling for 10 kinds of spiritual rapier attacks - AD_SHDW, AD_STAR, AD_MOON, AD_HOLY, AD_UNHY, AD_BLUD, AD_MERC, AD_PSON, AD_WET, AD_EFIR, and AD_EDRC. Of these, all but holy, unholy and mercury are currently used. This PR allows most of these to hit insubstantial targets if they would normally be 'vulnerable' or at least affected by that damage otherwise.

Shadowblades (edderkops et. al.) always hit insubstantial targets
Starlight & moonlight rapiers (various Eladrin) hit insubstantial targets if they're vulnerable to silver damage
Holy and unholy light-beams (unused) hit insubstantial targets if they're vulnerable to holy or unholy damage respectively (currently unused in practice but message handling existed)
Blades of rotten blood (Ascodel) hit insubstantial targets if they have blood
Soulblades (elocators) hit insubstantial targets if they have a mind
Blades of mercury (unused) never hit insubstantial targets (currently unused in practice, message handling existed, but unclear what the proper criteria are)
Water-jet blades (Uiscerre Eladrin) hit insubstantial targets if they are vulnerable to water damage, i.e. flaming or made of iron
Blades of fire (Fierna) hit insubstantial targets if they're not immune to fire damage, which includes monster innate resistances, standing on a Sigil of Cthugha, having Fafnir bound, and being a half-dragon with fire breath
Blades of poison (Naome) hit insubstantial targest if they're not poison resistant

Those are the only damage types used for spiritual rapiers now, so any new kinds of spiritual rapier attack will not automatically hit insubstantial targets unless handling is added. I tested most of these by forced polyforms, editing the damage type of black web shadowblades in xhity.c to holy/unholy and temporarily giving mercury rilmani proper blades instead of claws. They shouldn't crash on normal hit attempts, both in MvM/UvM and MvU but there's probably at least one edge case I missed.

Of these, all but holy, unholy and mercury are currently used. Starlight & moonlight rapiers (various Eladrin) hit insubstantial targets if they're vulnerable to silver damage
Holy and unholy light-beams (unused) hit insubstantial targets if they're vulnerable to holy or unholy damage respectively (currently unused in practice but message handling existed)
Blades of rotten blood (Ascodel) hit insubstantial targets if they have blood
Soulblades (elocators) hit insubstantial targets if they have a mind

Blades of poison (Naome) hit insubstantial targest if they're not poison resistant

Those are the only damage types used for spiritual rapiers now, so any new kinds of spiritual rapier attack will not automatically hit insubstantial targets unless handling is added. I tested most of these by forced polyforms, editing the damage type of black web shadowblades in xhity.c to holy/unholy and temporarily giving mercury rilmani proper blades instead of claws. They shouldn't crash on normal hit attempts, both in MvM/UvM and MvU but there's probably at least one edge case I missed.

column13: Adjust half-dragons and tripe
column20:
Half-dragon knights previously started with 20-30 tripe rations, which was incredibly overkill and sometimes ended up with you being nearly burdened from the get-go. This halves this number - previously it was derived from converting the 10-15 apples & carrots each (2 aum per, 50 nutrition per, for a total of 40-60 aum and 1000-1500 nutrition) to tripe rations for your carnivorous pseudodragon (10 aum per, 200 nutrition per, for a total of 200-300 aum and 4000-6000 nutrition). This PR tones that back to 10-15 tripe total, half the original value. This should allow you to not have to lug around a ridiculous number.
In addition, half-dragons are added to the check to make tripe a valid foodstuff. It's a little weird that pseudodragons apparently treat is as a treat, but other dragonkin dudes can't stand it either. Previously orcs could already eat it without issue, now half-dragons can as well.
column21:

This PR tones that back to 10-15 tripe total, half the original value. This should allow you to not have to lug around a ridiculous number.
In addition, half-dragons are added to the check to make tripe a valid foodstuff. It's a little weird that pseudodragons apparently treat is as a treat, but other dragonkin dudes can't stand it either. Previously orcs could already eat it without issue, now half-dragons can as well.

column13: Make the Star of Hypernotus display correctly w.r.t. the "star sapphire" material
column20:
Now shows as an "engraved blue-green star-shaped stone" when unidentified, and if you don't know the "star sapphire" gem. If you do know the star sapphire gem, shows up as an "engraved blue-green star-shaped star sapphire". Previously, this would show as an "engraved blue-green blue-green star-shaped stone", or an "engraved star sapphire blue-green star-shaped stone" or something like that. This fixes that.
Does some shenanigans to do so - special-cases the star of hypernotus to not have a material descriptor ever, and makes the 'artifact description' into "blue-green star shaped %s". The code that formats artifact description "%s"s into base names is then also special-cased to choose between "stone" and "star sapphire" (via the gem's identified proper name) as a base name instead.
Note: star sapphires are a kind of sapphire with a star-shaped pattern on/in them, so star-shaped star sapphire is not redundant (I think).
column21:

Previously, this would show as an "engraved blue-green blue-green star-shaped stone", or an "engraved star sapphire blue-green star-shaped stone" or something like that. This fixes that.

The code that formats artifact description "%s"s into base names is then also special-cased to choose between "stone" and "star sapphire" (via the gem's identified proper name) as a base name instead.
